scenes.text: You're in the DN office in the Nebraska Union. Your editor waves you over. 'Big crowd outside Love Library. Could be a protest, could be a flash mob. Go! You've got 5 hours.' What's your first move?

choices.text: Head straight to Love Library to see the crowd.
First, call your contact at UNL Police.
Check social media (Yik Yak, Twitter) first.

scenes.text: You call Officer Barta. 'Yeah, we've heard,' she says. 'It's a student group protesting the new dining hall menu changes. Seems peaceful.' This is good background info.

choices.text: Great. Now head to Love Library to get quotes.

scenes.text: You scroll Yik Yak. It's mostly jokes and vague posts ('What's happening at Love?'). You waste an hour and find no real information.

choices.text: Ugh. Okay, now I'll go to Love Library.

scenes.text: You arrive at Love Library. There are about 50 students chanting and holding signs. One person with a megaphone seems to be the leader.

choices.text: Interview the student with the megaphone.
Interview a random student in the crowd.
Take some photos and head back to write.

scenes.text: You talk to the leader, Jane. She gives you a passionate, well-sourced quote about rising costs and poor food quality. 'We're not leaving until we speak to administration!' she says. This is solid gold.

choices.text: This is enough. Head back to the office to write.

scenes.text: You grab a student nearby. 'I'm just here 'cuz my friend is,' he says. 'I think it's about... the food? I just want a picture for my Insta.' It's *a* quote, but not a great one.

choices.text: Okay, that was useless. I better go talk to the leader.
Good enough. Head back to write.

scenes.text: You're back in the newsroom. You look at the clock and your notes. It's time to publish.
This is a special scene that checks your final score.
You did it! Your story is fantastic, well-sourced, and on the front page before the deadline. Your editor is thrilled. You're a true Daily Nebraskan!
You published the story, but... it's weak. It's missing key sources and quotes. It gets buried on page 6. Your editor tells you 'better luck next time.'
The 6:00 PM deadline passes. You ran out of time! The story is old news, and the paper goes to print without your article. A rival paper got the scoop.
